I also signed 43. Commissions of army Officers, dated 15 February— John dined at Baron Krudener’s, and the family excepting John’s wife, who was unwell, attended an Evening party at Dr Lovell’s. Footbath.
18. V:30 Friday.— Sisters of Charity fair

My cold and hoarseness continues upon me, and having taken last night a warm foot-bath I omitted this morning my early walk— After Breakfast, Mr Lowrie the Secretary of the Senate brought me a Resolution of that body, calling for information respecting the removal of the Indian Agency from Fort Wayne— Mr Bailey introduced Dr. Adams President of a College at Charleston South Carolina, and a young man his pupil, named Middleton—a Grandson of Arthur Middleton, one of the signers of the Declaration of Independence— Mr Adams after having been a professor at the College in Charleston was chose President of the College of Geneva in the State of New-York; and is now going back to be President of the College at Charleston— Governor Barbour called with the Ontario Messenger a Newspaper published in the Western part of the State of New-York— It contained a Statement made by persons sent by the authority of the Government of New-York into the Territory of Arkansas, in pursuit of three persons suspected as accomplices in the murder of Morgan— The Statement charges Coll Cummins, Commandant of the Post at Cantonment Towson, with having collusively facilitated the escape of a man named King, acting as a Suttler to the Troops, and the most deeply implicated of them all in the suspicion of the murder— It is even asserted that Coll. Cummins denied the authority of the Secretary of War to give the Instruction, with which the pursuers had been furnished, ordering him to give all the aid in his power to detect and arrest the suspected culprits— This order had been given the last Autumn at the request of the late Governor Clinton— The Governor had received this newspaper yesterday, and another copy of it had been forwarded to me— He said he had immediately written to the publisher of the Paper, and to the person by whom the statement was made, asking further particulars relating to the allegations against Coll. Cummins— This I approved, and advised that a Copy of the Statement should be sent to Coll. Cummins himself, and that he should be called upon to defend himself against the allegations it contains— I gave Governor Barbour the Resolution of the Senate respecting the removal of the Indian Agency from Fort Wayne; which he said was a matter of altercation between the Senators from Indiana— Mr Dyer came to enquire if I could settle or compromise his claim to Lots in the City, upon which he had built houses— I had not fully examined his papers, but I promised to see the Commissioner of the public buildings, and to defer Mr Dyer all that should be in my power— Coll. Roberdeau brought me some burnet seed, and spoke of the observatory, the Meridian, and his Essay upon the Militia— At one O’Clock, I went with Abigail S. Adams and my Son George, to the Fair, held by the Sisters of Charity, for the benefit of the orphan girls, under their care. It was a repetition of the expedient resorted to last Winter, at Georgetown and in the City, and has been equally successful. After
making a few purchases we returned home; Mr Taylor of Kentucky called— He is an invalid pensioner, and has a claim before Congress for an increase of his pension— The bill for which has already passed the Senate— He told me he was one of the Candidates of the electoral ticket for the next Presidential Election— Mr Clay was here, and read me three Letters; one from Chief Justice Savage of New-York, expressing his regret at the newspaper paragraphs which have been in circulation, that he had been appointed Treasurer of the United States, and disclaiming all agency in there— Another from Jabez D. Hammond, earnestly recommending the appointment of Mr Savage as Treasurer— And one from Mr Goodenough of Maine, against the appointment of W. P. Preble, for the Agency concerning the North-eastern boundary— In the Evening, Mr Richardson, a member of the House from Massachusetts came and introduced Mr Lazell of Bridgwater, Mr Dyer of Providence, and another— Mr Webster was here afterwards, and informed me of the proceedings of both Houses, upon the Message which I sent them yesterday; in the House of Representatives it was referred to a Select Committee— M’Duffie, Gorham, P. P. Barbour, Oakley, Bell of Tennessee, Ingersoll and Ripley— Four opposition men, two friends, and one, supposed to be neutral, but really hostile— In the Senate after a debate several times resumed Mr Foote’s Resolution and the Message were both laid on the table, on the alledged ground of waiting to ascertain what will be done in the House— The vote was taken by yeas and nays; and was a party vote 24 and 22— Mr Parris and Mr Sanford, voting with the opposition, and thereby constituting the majority; and Smith of Maryland, Smith of South-Carolina, and M’Lane, voting with the friends of the Administration— Russell Jarvis sent in a Memorial or Petition, representing the origin of his attack, in his own manner, and attempting a justification of it— Mr Webster says that the only opposition member of the Senate who in debate admitted that the outrage was unjustifiable was Mr Macon— Our Servants attended the Fair this Evening, and heard threats of personal violence to my Son John openly avowed by a man said to be a Dr Hagan— My wife and his wife are both much alarmed— I will not be so myself without more unequivocal indicators of danger— I signed this day orders for the discharge from prison of Eli Davis and W. King, both in gaol here for assaults and batteries— There was an Evening party at Mr Clay’s, attended by my Sons and by Abby.
19. V:30. Rain. Saturday.

The weather deprived me again of my morning walk, as by the same cause I had lost that of yesterday morning— I walked out with George about a half an hour before dinner, and this was all the exercise, I could take in the day. The effect upon my Spirits superadded to that of the catarrhal cough which tortured me all the last Spring and is now returning upon me, is more than I can describe— Mr Graham the Commissioner of the General Land Office came for the Commissions of James P. Turner as Surveyor General of Lands South of Tennessee— He had applied for it at both the Department of State and of the Treasury; but it had not been found— It appeared by my Son John’s Record, that the Resolution of the Senate conferring the nomination, was sent to the Treasury Department the 29th. of February— Mr Graham said he would apply there again, and if it should not be found, another copy must be obtained from the Secretary of the Senate— Absalom Baker is an old Revolutionary Soldier who comes from the State of Illinois soliciting a pension from the Government, and contributions from individuals— While he was here, Mr Hayne the Senator from South-Carolina, came to introduce judge Davis from Columbia in that State— The old Soldier was lame from honourable wounds, but he became so loquacious, and so self-important in his patriotic dogmatism that I was obliged to call him out of my chamber, and furnish him with motives for going away. Mr Hayne and Mr Davis
made a short visit— Dr Porter of Roxbury was here; to be present at the Ordination of Mr Burnap at Baltimore next Wednesday— He told me he was accompanied here by his niece, and by Mrs Harrington— Mr Richmond, was from Augusta; and had a horse which he wanted me to purchase for 200 dollars. Mr Smith, Senator from South Carolina, introduced to me Coll. M’Cord from that State, who said he had been introduced to me before— Mr Briggs is Minister of Lexington, Massachusetts, and brought me a Letter of introduction from Mr Edward Everett. He has been passing the winter in Georgia, for his health, and now on his return home traveling on horseback, and proceeding this day towards Baltimore, where he is to attend at the ordination of Mr Burnap— Edward T. Tayloe came to solicit an appointment as Secretary of Legation abroad— Mr Bell, Senator from New-Hampshire was here, and conversed with me on various political topics— The nomination of General Macomb as Major General, and the dissatisfaction it has given to General Harrison, and to his friends particularly of the Ohio and Indiana Delegations— He said he was aware, that no other of the four Candidates could have been appointed without producing still greater excitement, and dissatisfaction— He thought the choice upon which I had fixed was the best; but he believed if the question of abolishing the Office of Major General should come again before the Senate it would prevail— A Resolution to that effect had been moved in the House of Representatives by Lewis Williams, immediately after the death of General Brown— Since the nomination of Macomb it had been brought forward again; and may very possibly pass in the House— It would now have the appearance of a censure both upon Macomb, and his nomination—but the same disposition would have been aroused though in other individuals, by the nomination of either of the other competitors, and to the measure itself, whether adopted or rejected I attach little importance— Mr Bell spoke also of the appointment of a Minister to Great-Britain, and was very anxious that it might be delayed until the next Session of Congress— He mentioned also the proceedings in the Senate upon my message relating to the assault of Russell Jarvis upon my Secretary; and thinks that the opposition party will for the sake of their own credit, do something to manifest their disapprobation of his conduct— I have no belief that they well. They brought him here for the purpose of assassination, and they cannot punish him for labouring in the vocation to which they called him— My Son received this day a Letter from Mr M’Duffie Chairman of the Committee of the House of Representatives upon my Message requesting his attendance before the Committee next Monday Morning— Mr Rush was here, and mentioned that General S. Smith the Chairman of the Committee of the Senate upon Finance had called on him this morning and with professions of friendship read him the Report he was about to make for the Committee to the Senate upon the finances— It sustains altogether the views of Mr Rush’s annual Report, and so far counteracts the Report of the Committee of Ways and Means to the House of Representatives, made by Mr M’Duffie, and which was throughout a violent and uncandid attack upon Mr Rush’s Report. Foot-bath
20. VI. Sunday— Rain. Fog.

The rain continued through great part of this day— Rode with George and Abby to the Unitarian Church. Heard Mr Stetson from John 1. 1. “In the beginning was the Word, and the Word was with God, and the Word was God.”— 14. [“]And the Word was made flesh and dwelt among us (and we beheld his glory, and the glory as of the only begotten of the father) full of grace and truth.”— And Psalm 33.6— “By the word of the Lord were the heavens made; and all the host of them by the breath of his Mouth.”— These texts the Preacher said he had brought together, as illustrative of the meaning of each other— He said he had been requested to give an exposition of the manner in which the unitarian doctrine could be understood conformably to those texts in the first chapter of John’s Gospel, and in particular how by the unitarian doctrines the character of Jesus Christ, could be distinguished from that of Moses, or of the eminent prophets— The Sermon was a solution of this question— He said they considered Jesus Christ, as the manifestation of the power of the one only God, in human form— That in the agency of human power, word and action were successive; but in the operations of divine power the word and the action were identical— God said let there be light, and there was light; and thus the word was with God, and the word was God— Creative power was thus conferred upon Christ, the Son of God, with which he wrought Miracles upon Earth— It was thus that he became the Saviour and Redeemer
of the world, this character was therefore altogether different from that of Moses, or of any of the prophets— This exposition was ingenious and forcible, but was not that of all Unitarians. It would not have been sanctioned by the late Mr Little—he admitted no difference of nature between Moses and Jesus— He believed Christ to have been a mere man—the Son of Joseph and Mary, and that the powers conferred upon him as a Minister from God, differed only in degree from those of Moses, or any of the prophets— With George I walked home from the morning service— Edward Wyer came in, fresh from Rio de Janeiro, whither he had been sent with despatches to William Tudor, appointed Chargé d’Affaires to that Government— Mr Tudor whose Commission has been sent to him at Lima in Peru, and who received it only in December, had not arrived at Rio de Janeyro when Wyer reached there— Wyer proceeded on to Montevideo, where he saw J. M. Forbes, our Chargé d’Affaires to the Government of Buenos Ayres, who has been many months afflicted, even to the disqualification for business by the Gout—and was upon an excursion to Montevideo, whence he had been to Rio de Janeyro for the recovery of his health— Wyer arrived two days since at New-York, and speaks of having had an extremely boisterous passage home— Attended with George the afternoon Service at St John’s Church— Heard Mr Hawley read the Evening prayer for the second Sunday after Easter, and preach from Romans 3.21. [“]But now the righteousness of God, without the Law is manifested, being witnessed by the law and the prophets; 22. Even the righteousness of God, which is by faith of Jesus Christ unto all and upon all them that believe; for there is no difference.”— After three days of rain and fogs the weather finally cleared away this Evening.
21. V:30— Monday— Walk with George—at Hardings— Garden

My Catarrhal cold is yet troublesome, but I walked this morning with George round the Capitol Square. We met Mr Harding the Painter, and called at his chamber where we saw his collection of Portraits and among them mine, which he had packed up to send to New-York, but opened, that George might see it. He has good likeness of all the Judges of the U.S. Supreme Court, and has begun a picture of them, as in Session, upon the Bench— My Son John went before the Committee of the House of Representatives on my Message of the 17th. and delivered to them a written statement of facts relating to the assault upon him by Russell Jarvis, and to the occasion whence it arose— Mr Crockett, a member of the House of Representatives from Tennessee, introduced to me, Messrs. Wommock, Elliot, Smith, and another, from North and South-Carolina—travellers and Strangers— Mr Foot the Senator from Connecticut introduced his two Sons, transient visitors to the City— General Duncan, Member of the House of Representatives from Illinois introduced a Mr Mather of that State, who was a Commissioner for laying out a Road to the boundary of Mexico— I urged them to prevail upon the Legislature of Illinois, at some time when they should be laying out a new County, to call it by the name of LaSalle— Mr Mather said they had once tried to get a County so named without success. Mr Ticknor and Mr Prescott are visitors from Boston— George Watkins from the Department of State came for a note from the Mexican Minister Mr Obregon, complaining of the seizure at Key West of a prize to a Mexican privateer carried in there— Mr Clay afterwards called, and we had some conversation concerning it— The prize had been so much damaged, in the capture, that she could not depart from the Port without repairs; and those repairs could not be made without selling a part of the cargo to pay for them— The question is whether this can be allowed consistently with the Laws of Neutrality— Mr Clay said he could find no authority to the point; and that having accidentally seen Mr Webster, he had enquired of him if he recollected any such case, but he did not— The seizure by the Collector had been upon the charge that the vessel which made the prize had been fitted out
in our own Ports— And Mr Obregon’s Note complains especially and repeatedly, that when the seizure was made the Mexican flag, was hauled down— I found in Wheaton upon Captures some remarks on a case nearly resembling this, but not identically the same— Mr Clay mentioned also his negotiation with the Prussian Charge d’Affaires, Niederstetter, with whom some question has arisen with regard to two Articles of the projected Treaty— One upon the free ships free goods principle, and the other upon the definition of blockade— With regard to the first Mr Niederstetter was not authorised to agree to the limitation by which the principle of free ships free goods should be recognized only in cases when the enemy of the belligerent acknowledges the same—and it is doubtful, whether the Senate would advise to the ratification of the Article, without the limitation— I said the Article might be postponed for further consideration, as Had been done in the Treaty of 1798— Mr Clay spoke likewise of his conferences with Barron Krudener, the Russian Minister, concerning the proposal on our part, to refer the question of our North-Eastern boundary to the arbitration of the Emperor Nicholas— The Baron thinks the Emperor would accept, though with reluctance the task of arbitrator, but said he might perhaps accept on condition, that the parties should previously make a last effort to adjust the dispute by direct Negotiation between the parties themselves—an idea with which I was much pleased— Mr William Lee brought me statements of several claims which have been allowed by the accounting officers of the Treasury; being the same in principle with those now claimed by Amos Binney; and he asked leave for Binney to come and see me again himself to which I readily agreed— Mr Asbury Dickins, Secretary to the Columbian Institute brought me the subscription Book of the Society, containing the names of the members subscribed by themselves with the dates of their respective admissions— I subscribed my name, as of 6. October 1817. Major Hoops came to enquire if I had examined his Dissertation, upon the Military Store keeper’s Office— I had not had time to get them through— Major Hoops read me another Letter, and will call again in a few days— Governor Barbour called upon the subject of his parleys with the Arkansas Cherokees, and a proposition which he thinks of making them; but upon which I advised him to consult with Mr Sevier the Delegate from the Territory— Mr Southard called for certain papers relating to the questions about the Staff Officers of the Marine Corps, which I accordingly gave him— He had sent me despatches received by Mr Wyer from Commodore Biddle— I sent Message N. 27. to the Senate, with the Treaty of limits with Mexico— 3. fresh apple-seeds appeared in Seedling Pot. N. 2.
22. VI. Tuesday— Walk with George round Capitol Square— Met Foy.

In walking round the Capitol Square, we met Mr. Foy, and examined some of the trees and plants in the enclosure— The tree of Heaven or Tallow tree, the Cerasus Canadensis, Judas tree or red bud— the arbor vitae— the sweet Kern of Missouri a plant now in bloom, and some others— I received an anonymous Letter charging misconduct upon my Son John, which I gave him to read— Mr Pleasonton and Mr Garnsey, Member of the House of Representatives from New-York, came with renewed complaints against the official conduct of Myndert M Dox, Collector of the Port of Buffalo, with certain Letters and documents raising against him a violent suspicion of fraud. I desired Mr Pleasonton to lay these papers before the Secretary of the Treasury and request him to institute forthwith an investigation of the facts, and if proper to remove Dox from Office— Mr Woodcock a member of the House from New-York came and introduced a Mr Gifford, from that State— Mr Woodcock intimated that he should renew his application in behalf of the Cadet Hughes; on the expected passage of the Bill for making an addition to the Corps of Engineers— Captain Hills was here; going tomorrow for Augusta, Maine: and renewing the application to be stationed here, or in this neighborhood— Captain Dana, and Mr Goodman are visitors from Boston— Mr Fendall and Mr Brent
came from the Department of State, concerning the several copies of Mitchell’s map belonging there, and for which I had sent. Fendall spoke of the Report of the Committee of the House of Representatives, upon the Expenditures of the Department of State: which proposes withholding in future the appropriations for additions to the Library— Lewis Williams a member of the House of Representatives, from North-Carolina, introduced his brother Dr Williams; from Tennessee— The Doctor proceeds homewards to-morrow— Mr James Wilson, a member of the House from Pennsylvania, introduced a Mr Ramsay from his District— Mr William Sullivan of Boston was here upon a transient visit. Travelling for his health, and accompanied by his daughter— They are proceeding Northward to-morrow or the next day— Coll. Roberdeau was here with some question of the fund from which Mr Montandon’s bill for repairs on the Chronometers and other Mathematical Instruments— Governor Barbour came still perplexed with the claims of Arkansas-Cherokee Indians— Mr Sevier the delegate from the Territory earnestly remonstrates against the projected Treaty by which a portion of Lands westward of the Territory should be assigned to them for their permanent and final residence—giving them an enlarged space to settle upon—more in quantity than in quality— While Mr Cobb, and the other Southern proprietors are extremely anxious to have the Treaty concluded. I proposed that by the means of friendly Senators we should ascertain in what light they would consider that project; and whether it would probably receive the advice of the Senate to the Ratification— A young man named Chandler—from Louisiana, recommended by the late Governor and having learnt the language, comes with a repeated application for an appointment of Captain in the Marine Corps, for which I referred him to the Secretary of the Navy— Mr Butman, member of the House of Representatives from Maine came to speak of an appointment of an Agent for the prosecution of the North-eastern boundary question— He explained to me as well as he could how it happened that Mr Sprague, and J. F. Wingate signed the recommendation of Judge Preble—and finally Butman himself thought it would be best to appoint him— Butman shewed me also a Letter from Isaac Ilsley at Portland; urging the further postponement of any appointment of Postmaster there. Mr Clay called concerning the draft a Commercial Treaty with Prussia that he had prepared. It consisted of 14. Articles, chiefly relating to the system of equalizing duties. With one Article, re-postponing the question of free ships free goods— But omitting all the maritime Articles, of the two former Treaties— I recommended to Mr Clay, to insert one additional Article, reviving all those of the former Treaties which present circumstances render still useful— I observed that they might be all inserted in a single article, enumerating each of them by numbers. I thought the abandonment of all those Articles, would manifest an indifference to them, which would be industriously used against us, and it would multiply the diversities of our Treaties with different powers: while our policy is to assimilate as much as possible our obligatory Treaties together— I sent Messages to the House of Representatives N. 10—with copy of an Opinion of the Attorney General, upon the award of the Emperor Alexander on the Slave Indemnity Question— John was told by Mr Gorham, that the Committee on my Message, would summon him again before them, at the demand of Russel Jarvis who claimed the right of cross-examining him— George spent part of the Evening with me in my chamber—
23. V:15 Wednesday— Round Capitol Square alone.

Walk round the Capitol Square alone— Garden visit— No new appearance of vegetation among my trees. A seventh apple seed came up in my seedling pot N. 2— My Son John received a note from G. M’Duffie Chairman of the Committee on my Message, informing him that there seemed to be a discrepancy between the statement delivered by him to the Committee, and the testimony of some of the witnesses produced by Mr Jarvis; that the Committee would sit this morning till 9 O’Clock, and he, John, was at Liberty to attend and cross examine the witnesses, if he saw fit— John went to the Capitol accordingly before 9. but the Committee had adjourned, and Mr M’Duffie said he would give John notice when they should meet again— Dr Todsen was here twice—an applicant again for employment— The Secretary of the Navy having dismissed him from the Agency to the African Colony. Messrs. Bartley and Davenport Members of the House of Representatives from Ohio introduced two of their Constituents, Gibson and Rawson— Mr Miller, a member of the House from Pennsylvania, brought a Petition from W. Clew convict of stealing two thousand dollars, from a Bank, in Bills—sentenced to three years imprisonment—of which about six Months have elapsed, and recommended by the Petit Jury which convicted him, to pardon— Mr De Graff, a member of the House from New-York introduced two of his Constituents: Child and Sherwood, a very extensive Mail Contractor— De Graff again lamented the necessity he was under of being an opposition man, and said they should not catch him again—by which I understood that he knows he will not be re-elected— Dr Mease came to inform me of his intention to leave the City on Friday to return to Philadelphia; but he agreed to stay over, and dine with us that day. His Manual for the culture of silk is nearly ready for delivery; and eight thousand copies of it have been ordered to be printed by the two Houses of Congress— There is it appears a Bill before Congress, for the appointment of an Agent to collect historical Documents from the Archives of the public Offices in England— The Doctor thinks it should be extended to the collection of similar documents from France; where some of the most important to Louisiana, and the Western States will be found— He thinks it should also comprehend the collection of useful Patent Machinery, a kind of research which he believes might be pursued to very great public benefit— And he said he should be gratified to receive the appointment to this Agency, for which he would wish for no compensation beyond the payment of his expenses— Mr Alexander Scott of Georgetown, applied again for an Office. His present object is the superintendency of the Penitentiary. Mr Taylor, member of the House of Representatives from New-York spent part of the Evening here— Miss Ann M’Knight came to pass a week with our young Ladies— My Sons George and John dined at the British Minister Mr Vaughan’s, it being St. George’s day and the celebration of the King of England’s birth-day. There was also a Ball this Evening at Mr J. S. Johnston’s— I wrote with great difficulty in the Evening.
24. IV:30. Thursday— Round Capitol Square.

Walked alone round the Square— Visited the Garden— No appearance of new vegetation in my seedling beds— Some of the walnuts of last years growth are putting out their leaves; but the clay-soil of the ground bakes almost to the hardness of a brick, so that the young trees are so clogged that they cannot make their way through to the Service— Impatient at their not appearing, I desired Ouseley to spade up one of the rows where I had planted cherry stones last Summer— Of a row of 36. I found only one stone unchanged, and one vegetating with a radicle and Cotyledons, which would have come up perhaps in a month— I cannot yet satisfy myself why so small a proportion of the seeds and stones that I plant do come up— The Strawberries are in full blossom— A white Iris at the gate open— No fresh flowers.
I sent for Mr Elgar and read to him the memorial of William B. Dyer, complaining of injustice suffered by him in the sale and resale of certain city lots— Mr Elgar told me other circumstances relating to those transactions which confirmed my conviction that I had no authority to interpose, though Dyer has been harshly dealt with, and advantage has apparently been taken, both of his imprudence and of his necessities— Mr Mather of the State of Illinois called— He enquired of me whether the late Mr Daniel Pope Cook had two years ago; when the Bill for adding three judges to the Bench of the U.S. Supreme Court was before Congress and expected to pass, delivered to me a recommendation, signed by most of the members of the Legislature of Illinois in behalf of judge Nathaniel Pope, for one of those appointments— I said I believed he had. I certainly had received such a recommendation, and Mr Cook had been anxiously desirous that judge Pope should receive the appointment. Mr Mather said he was well assured it was so—but exertions had been made before Mr Cook’s death, to produce a coolness between him and judge Pope, and one of the means used had been an intimation to judge Pope that Mr Cook never had delivered to me that recommendation. Eleanor Wells was the woman who came some time since to say she had a petition before Congress of a Pension; having lost her husband, and two Sons in the public service. Mr Chambers the Senator from Maryland called to have some conversation with me upon public affairs— He expressed much solicited respecting the appointment of a Minister to Great Britain; and although entertaining a very high opinion of Mr Webster, thought that the appointment of him would be inexpedient, both as to the political effect, and because his removal would be an irreparable loss in the Senate. Mr Clay came with a draft of an Article for the Treaty with Prussia, renewing most of the Articles of the last Treaty— He also told me that the State of his Health was such that he should be compelled to resign his Office— It was becoming impossible for him to discharge its duties and he could not consent to hold an office without discharging its duties— He mentioned it now that I might have time to make provision to supply his place before the close of the Session of Congress— His good wishes for the success of the administration would be as warm as if he had remained a member of it— But his weakness was constantly increasing— A relaxation from public duties was indispensable; and he must go home, and die or get better. His disorder is a general decay of the vital powers, a paralytic torpidity and numbness which began at the lower extremity of his left limb; and from the foot has gradually risen up the leg and now approaches to the hip— I told him that his communication was of the most painful character to me— That I would still hope he might as the Spring advanced find himself so much better as to continue in the Office, and while preparing for the contingency of his resignation should he persist in thinking it unavoidable, I wished him to take some days for consideration if a more cheering expedient might not be embraced— Mr B. O. Tyler introduced a Mr Benjamin Williams, who applies for the appointment of keeper of the Penitentiary, and brought with him a multitude of recommendatory Letters. Governor Barbour and Mr Southard were here together— The Governor has concluded after consulting with several friendly members of the Senate to make his Treaty with the Arkansas Cherokees— Both the Governor and Mr Southard spoke of the condition of Mr Clay’s health; and Mr Southard said he doubted whether he would live a month longer— I do not think his case so desperate, but there can be no doubt that a temporary relaxation from public duties can alone save his life, and give him a possible prospect of recovery— Mr Letcher of Kentucky was here in the Evening and made remarks to the same effect— This is in every point of view a disastrous occurrence; and is among those of deep humiliation which are thickening around me— The younger part of our family dined at Mr Frye’s, but my wife and Miss M’Knight dined below with me.
25. IV:45. Friday— Round Capitol Square with George— Rain— Dining party.

Planted 100 of the yard cherry stones, and 1. Apricot Stone in seedling pot N. 5. 7 yard cherry-stones 2. Raisin seeds and 9. Apple seeds from a rotten Newtown Pippin, in seedling pot N. 4 and an 8th. apple seed shewed itself in Seedling pot N. 2 My Son John was called again this morning before the Committee of the House of Representatives upon my Message relating to the attack upon him— Jarvis was offered at his option a hearing before the Committee, or at the Bar of the House— He claimed the hearing before the Committee, by Counsel, and his associate of the Telegraph Duff Green was admitted as such— By him my Son was this morning very closely cross examined— William Thorpe of Missouri came with a renewed application of his claims as Suttler and as Administrator of deceased Soldiers— He said Mr John Sergeant would come and converse with me in his behalf; and he repeated all his old arguments, saying that Mr Van Buren, Chairman of the Judiciary Committee of the Senate had deceived him— He was going on, repeating his seven times told tale, when Mr Woodcock, member of the House from New-York came in, and he withdrew— The object of Mr Woodcock’s visit was to say to me that great apprehensions were entertained that Mr Webster would be nominated as Minister to Great Britain; and that the political effect of his appointment would be ruinous to the cause of the Administration in New-Hampshire, in Maine, and in New-York— Visitors in succession came; Mr Powell of Virginia; Mr Allen, member of the House from Massachusetts with Mr Calhoun of Springfield, Mr Pearce member from Rhode-Island, with a young man from that State named Bullock— Mr Smith the United States judge in East-Florida, who spoke of the Africans lately brought to St. Augustine from Key West; where they had been stranded in the Spanish Prize Ship Guerrero— He said the Marshal to whose custody they were had requested of him some order concerning them; which he had declined giving; being of opinion that the Act of Congress of 9. March 1819. did not apply to them— I told him that I had the same opinion and proposed sending a Message to Congress asking a supplementary provision, to enable the Executive to dispose of them. Captain Bache and Mr Graham, are of the Engineers— Mr Dorsey, member of the House from Maryland, introduced Mr Chapeman, who came to solicit the appointment of Consul at the Cape de Verd Islands— I told him that there was already a nomination to that office before the Senate— Mr Dorsey mentioned that he had abstained from calling on me and conversing with me upon the outrage committed upon my Son John, at the Capitol, which he witnessed— He told me now all the circumstances relating to it: and he declares that my Son’s conduct was as spirited and manly, as it could be— Mr Dorsey had made his statement to the Committee, but is to be examined before them again; and to undergo a Cross examination— Messrs. Rush, Clay and Southard were here together— Mr Rush left with me a bundle of papers relating to reciprocal complaints against each other of W. Pinkney, Collector of the Customs at Key West, and of Captain Doane of the Revenue Cutter Marion; and relating to the seizure of a prize to a Mexican Brig of War— He had also an Account of Judge Smith of East-Florida, and one of his Clerk; for acting two years as Commissioner and Clerk in examining the cases of complaint by Spanish Subjects for wrongs suffered by them during General Jackson’s invasion of Florida, in the Seminole War. Mr Rush thinks there should be a limitation of time to the reception of these complaints—and that the account of the judge runs up, almost to extravagance— Mr Southard had sent me a budget of despatches received from Commodore Biddle— Mr Clay mentioned a conference he had just had, with Mr Niederstetter the Prussian Charge d’Affaires, in which he had consented to revive the Articles from 12 to 24 inclusive of the Treaty of 1798—and Article 12 of the Treaty of 1785. but said he had no instructions authorising him to revive the Article abolishing the private War upon the Ocean—
Signed land-grants 7 Sent Message to the Senate N. 28. with a Treaty of Commerce with the United Mexican States— We had company to dine— B. V. and F Crowninshield S. A. Foot and his two Sons, Jonathan Hunt, Mr Mather, Dr James Mease, Alfred H. Powell, W. H. Prescott, John Reed, John W. Taylor, George Ticknor, John Varnum, Daniel Webster, and David Woodcock— Lewis Williams sent an excuse— There was an evening Ball at Mr Southard’s; attended by our young family— Heavy rain this evening.
26. VI. Saturday— Walk round Capitol Square before dinner.

Rain almost the whole night, and the morning so foul that I postponed my daily walk till four in the afternoon— Mr Bartley, a member of the House of Representatives from Ohio, came with the Revd. Mr Davis of the Methodist foundery Church— They are undertaking to build another near the Post-Office, for which Mr Davis had a subscription Book, and solicited my contribution— Without subscribing I promised to pay him or his order 50 dollars for the object— George Watkins came from Mr Clays, and left with me a Note from Mr Niederstetter to Mr Clay accepting the Article to revive sundry Articles of the former Treaties, and proposing the insertion of the 15th. Article of our late Treaty with Sweden respecting Blockades— I received a Note from Mr Everett enquiring what sum of money had been paid to Daniel Pope Cook, for his Agency to the Island of Cuba— I sent for Mr Daniel Brent, and requested him to furnish me copies of all the papers relating to that Agency, with that of my Certificate relating to the payment— Mr Everett called, with Mr Ripley, Minister of Concord, who has been at Baltimore, attending the Ordination of Mr Burnap, which took place last Wednesday— I mentioned to Mr Everett the amount of money paid to Mr Cook, and that there was probably a small balance due to his Estate. He asked if it might be mentioned to the Committee— I said if it was probable the report of the Committee would allude to this transaction, in a way to reflect upon the memory of Mr Cook, it might be mentioned; for if such an attempt should be made in the Report of the Committee I should feel it a duty to his Memory to make the fact public by a Communication to the House— Mr Lowrie the Secretary of the Senate brought me three Resolutions of that body: two calling for an immense Mass of information from the Registers and Receivers of the Land Offices and from the Marshals of the States and Territories where there are public Lands on Sale, to be laid before the Senate at their next Session— The third was the confirmation of the nominations last sent in, excepting that of Major General and a few others— Dr Huntt was here—returned from his late excursion to Philadelphia. I consulted him respecting my own health which is not good— My Catarrhal cough has much subsided, but the functions of the stomach have not been restored to their natural vigour. He advised me to continue taking the white mustard seed, and boneset tea. I spoke to him of the health of Mr Clay— He says that Mr Clay’s disorder does not threaten life— That the torpid numbness which is creeping upwards from his feet is a neuralgia—nervous, and not paralytic. That Dr. Chapman, to whom he described the symptoms, is of the same opinion concerning it with himself; but that Mr Clay must have a relaxation from severe public duties, tranquility, abstemious diet, and exercise— Mr Clay himself called immediately after Huntt had left me. The Treaty with Prussia is in preparation. I agreed to Mr Niederstetter’s proposal to introduce into it the 18th. Article of our last Treaty with Sweden, concerning blockades. Mr Clay was desirous of introducing a more precise definition of blockades, but Niederstetter cannot venture upon it without Instructions. I told Mr Clay that I had reflected upon his tender of his resignation
and hoped he would reconsider it— I mentioned to him Dr Huntts opinion of his case, and proposed to him to take an excursion of a few weeks or even Months, leaving the current duties of the Department of State to be performed by the Chief Clerk Mr Brent, and with regard to those duties of a more important character which may occur, I said I would give my own attention to them and if necessary would remain here the whole summer for that purpose— He appeared disposed to make this trial, and said he thought of going next week to Philadelphia to consult Doctors Physick and Chapman upon his case. He said he had little hope of surviving, and had so made up his mind as to set but little value upon life— With regard to the political effect of his resigning, he scarcely knew what it would be— If it should tend in some parts of the Country to relax the exertions of our friends, it would perhaps abate the virulence of opposition in other quarters— I told him it was my wish to set aside all consideration of political effect in this matter— His life and his health should be paramount to all other considerations. If he had made up his mind philosophically to estimate life itself at a low value, I had made up mine to a much lower estimate of political life— I was prepared for whatever might ensue; and like him could not foresee what might be the effect of his withdrawing from the Administration— It would be exceedingly painful to me to part with him, as I had fondly hoped we should continue together at least until the close of my present term of service: yet if it should be indispensable for the restoration of his health I would look exclusively to that— He received with much feeling of gratification these remarks, and said that the interest manifested by his friends in his present situation, deeply affected him— He said he had receive this morning another testimonial of it for which he was profoundly grateful— Some of his friends had conjectured that pecuniary embarrassments in his private concerns contributed to the present unhappy state of his health—and they had met, and made up a sum of money, the use of which they had offered him for his relief— Their impression however had been erroneous— He was not free from debt, but there was nothing in the state of his affairs which required this assistance, and he had accordingly declined their offer— Mr Frye came and introduced Coll. Walbach, Mr Silsbee the Senator from Massachusetts, his Son, and General Van Rensselaer, a young named George B. Taylor, who applied for an appointment as a Surgeon in the Army— Governor Barbour called chiefly to speak of Mr Clay; and to suggest precisely the proposal which I had made to him, and he had accepted of trying the effect of a temporary relaxation from public business, before taking his final determination to resign— I directed the appointment of Joseph Doty of New-Jersey as keeper of two new Light-Houses on the Highlands of Navesink N.J. with a Salary of 600 dollars a year— My Sons dined with Mr Rush, and the family attended in the Evening a Ball at Baron Krudeners—
27. V:15. Sunday.

Dr Huntt called on me this morning, and said he had seen Mr Clay— He persists in the opinion that his complaints are not immediately threatening to life, and that they are entirely under the controul of medical treatment. He has again advised him to go as soon as practicable to Philadelphia, and consult Doctors Physick and Chapman: and he urges an indispensable tranquility; relaxation from public cares, and a severely abstemious regimen— I attended three times with George at the Unitarian Church— Heard this morning Dr Ezra Ripley of Concord from 2. Corinthians 4.13. “We also believe, and therefore speak” and again at half past three in the afternoon, from Luke 14.18. “And they all with one consent began to make excuse”— Dr Ripley is 77 years of age, and his Style of preaching is that of the old liberal school— Between the Services I had visits from Mr Stephen Higginson of Boston, and Mr Everett— At half past seven in the Evening we heard Mr Henry Ware of New-York, a son of the Professor at Cambridge, of distinguished reputation among the controversial Unitarians, but not very impressive as a preacher. The leisure of the day was occupied in reviewing the Oration of Cicero for Quintius, at the request of my Son Charles, but I was not able to finish it— George sat with me an hour of the Evening, discussing Lord Bacon’s Essays.
28. V:15. Monday. Round Capitol Square with George. Dinner party.

After the morning walk with George, visiting the Garden, I found in the Eastern Seedling bed, that a tree which had shewn itself last week, but which I did not then know was a White Oak— I fix therefore on the last week in April, for the appearance in this Climate of Oaks from the Acorn planted the preceding autumn— I afterwards visited the western enclosure, and discovered there several Oaks from the Acorns planted by Mr Foy last November— There are also a few peaches, cherries, plums Apricots, and the rows of Apples planted last Month by Antoine, coming up. The 8th. and 9th apple seeds are also coming up in seedling pot N. 2. Several of last years walnuts have put forth their leaves— Mr Southard came this morning after breakfast, with Dr Condict, member of the House from New-Jersey, and introduced a General Darcy, from that State— Lieutenant Schuler came to set forth his grievances and persecutions for the consideration of which I referred him to the Secretary of War— Dr Browne, the new Superintendent of the Patent-Office called with Mr Brent. Mr Temple of Vermont, called with Mr Mallary, a member of the House. Mr Rush and Mr Clay were here together— Mr Rush brought papers relating to the seizure at Key West of a Prize to a Mexican armed brig, and mutual complaints against each other of the Collector at Key West W Pinkney; and the Captain of the Revenue Cutter Marion, Doane. Mr Clay mentioned Notes that he had received from the Mexican Minister Obregon, and from the Spanish Chargé d’Affaires Tacon, each claiming the restoration of this prize— Also a Note from him to the Swedish Charge d’Affaires Baron Stackelberg, concerning the construction of an Article of the recent Treaty with Sweden in its application to Norway. William Lee called with Mr John Gray of Boston, who is on his return from New-Orleans, where he has been passing the Winter. General Daniel Parker brought, and gave me to read a Letter from a Captain Le Conte now at Paris, on a furlough; and who claims brevet promotion for ten years of service— The Letter had also much political speculation, upon European affairs, and expressed some opinions not favourable to the estimation of our Minster in France but without any specific complaint against him— Mr Ellis of the Senate, and Mr Forward of the House of Representatives from the Committee of Enrolled Bills, brought me eight Acts which had passed both Houses and which I signed. Mr Wilson a member of the House of Representatives from Pennsylvania, introduced a young man, one of his Constituents named Hughes— The Revd. Richard Allen, is a black man, and a preacher from Philadelphia. He came with two persons of his own colour, one named Nathaniel Adams, and the other Prout, belonging to Georgetown— Mr Strong a member of the House from New-York, introduced the Revd. Mr Chester of Albany, and his brother, Mr Chester of Philadelphia— I sent Message to the House of Representatives N. 11. with a Report from the Secretary of State, and copies of the Correspondence with the British Government, relating to the Colonial trade. We had company to dine John Bailey, John Barney, Ichabod Bartlett, Mr Calhoun of Springfield, Mrs Chapman daughter of Mr Temple, Edward Everett, Stephen Higginson, Robert P. Letcher, Rollin C. Mallary, Dutee J. Pearce, Ezra Ripley, Horatio Seymour, Nathaniel Silsbee and his Son, Peleg Sprague, Henry R. Storrs, Robert Temple and his daughter, and John C. Wright—with my wife; my two sons and John’s wife and Abigail S. Adams 24. at table— I had after dinner some conversation with Mr Seymour, and executed a Bond to Edward H. Robbins, judge of Probate as Executor of Ward N. Boylston— My Son George executed it also as surety. Mr Bailey witnessed
our signing and sealing— My brother is still to execute the Bond, as the second surety— Miss M’Knight left us this morning—
29. V. Tuesday— Round Capitol Square, alone— Rain.

Found in the Eastern Seedling bed in the Garden, an Oak coming up from the Battle ground Acorns planted on the 20th. of last October— I afterwards visited the western enclosure, or Nursery, and found upon examination that a number of Acorns which I had planted with Foy, round its Northern border, were coming up— These were planted 9. November last— Of those planted some days later on the other borders none yet appear— I had this day 28 visitors— Mr Lowrie the Secretary of the Senate brought me the Treaty of Limits with Mexico, and a Resolution of the Senate advising and consenting to its ratification— Coll. Thomas came to express his thanks for the appointment which the Secretary of War has given him of Suttler, to the troops ordered down to the North-Eastern Boundary— Mr Pierson a member of the House of Representatives from New Jersey, introduced a Mr Clason from that State— William Lee came with Mr Appleton, his Nephew and Mr Rice of Boston— Mr Rush was here, and sent me a correspondence between W. Pinkney, Collector at Key West, and the Spanish Admiral La Borde, on the Mexican privateers and their prizes which have now taken refuge at that Island. Also a Letter from Governor Edwards of Illinois, applying for twelve Sections of Land in addition to 24. already set off as a donation from Congress to the State, three or four years since— Lieutenant Farley has been for some time soliciting a furlough to visit Europe— He has now obtained it; but finds a difficulty in availing himself of it, for want of funds— He came to enquire if he could not be employed as a bearer of despatches; but there is no occasion to employ anyone upon that service at present. Lieutenant Farley is a West Point Scholar and has a great talent for drawing; of which he shewed me several Specimens. Governor Kent of Maryland paid me a short visit— Governor Barbour mentioned that he had concluded to make a new Treaty with the Arkansas Cherokee Indians— Having consulted several members of the Senate, he has no doubt that it will receive the sanction of that body; and he thinks it will be much opposed by no one in Congress except the Delegate from the territory of Arkansas, Sevier— Dr Watkins called and spoke to me of a project which Mr Southard had mentioned to me yesterday—which was that he Watkins should purchase of P. Force the Establishment of the National Journal; resign his office of fourth Auditor of the Treasury, and devote himself entirely to the editing of the Paper. Force has been unfortunate with it, and has neither funds nor credit to sustain it any longer— The Doctor thinks he can procure funds at Baltimore for the purchase, and that he can make it more profitable than his Office of Auditor— I could give no Advice upon the subject, but I told Dr Watkins I thought it would be a safe speculation for him— For in the event of the success of the Election the paper would certainly be supported; and in the event of its failure, he would certainly be dismissed from his Office—of which he said he was perfectly aware— Mr Brent left with me a recommendation from Mr Gales the Mayor, of C. C. Coote for the appointment of a Justice of the Peace— General Barnard, a Senator, and Mr Anderson a member of the House of Representatives from Pennsylvania, came to speak of the claim of Major Anderson to a Brevet— I told them that I had kept this case and several others for advisement, while a proposition was before Congress for the repeal of the Law concerning brevets. A bill for that purpose has just been reported to the Senate by their Military Committee— Mr Woodcock, a member of the House of Representatives from New-York,
introduced a Mr Hallett who is under prosecution for enlisting men, for a Mexican Cruizer at New-York— Mr Hallett petitions for a discontinuance of the persecution alledging that he had no knowledge of the violation of the Law by these enlistments— I referred the case to the District Attorney at New-York, with directions to supersede the prosecution, if the fact be ascertained as alleged by Mr Hallett— Mr Dorsey, member of the House from Maryland, called with Mr Jenifer of that State, and Mr Storrs of New-York, with Mr Craig, heretofore a member of the House from that State— Mr Clay was occupied with Notes from Mr Rebello, the Brazilian Charge d’Affaires, and from Mr Obregon the Mexican Minister, to both of which he is replying— He read me a Letter from J. J. Crittenden in Kentucky, full of encouraging expectations, and one from Edward Ingersoll at Philadelphia, in deep discomfiture at the appointment of T. Sergeant as Postmaster at Philadelphia— My Sons dined at the Count de Menous, the Charge d’Affaires of France, and spent the Evening at Mr T. Munroe’s— I had for evening visitors the Revd. Mr Bancroft of Worcester, with Mr Davis, and afterwards J. Reed and J. Locke members of the House of Representatives from Massachusetts. This flood of visitors is crazing.
30. V. Wednesday— Round Capitol Square— rain.

I omitted mentioning the application yesterday of Jeremy Robinson, renewed for compensation for old services and for employment under the Government again— He now brought a recommendatory Letter from Mr Monroe, the late President, addressed to Coll R. M. Johnson of the Senate— This Letter he obtained by a visit to Mr Monroe, at his Seat in Loudoun County last week— He repeated to me for the fiftieth time all the allegations of his claims and after listening to him near an hour I said he knew that more than three years since I had nominated him to the Senate as Consul at Rio Janeiro and the nomination had been confirmed by the Senate— That his Commission had been made out, signed, and ready to be delivered to him, when it was withheld, in consequence of remonstrances from persons of respectable character at Salem, charging him with misconduct in trusts committed to him by them— He had been informed that until those transactions should be satisfactorily explained, no office under the Government of the United States could be conferred upon him— This satisfactory explanation had not been given and in this state of things, renewed solicitations on his part, were but a useless waste of time— He thanked me for the candour of this declaration, and said he should proceed to act according to my advice— D. J. Pearce told me, when he dined here last Monday, that Robinson told him that I had given him an office worth nothing which he had therefore declined. He said Robinson had also assured him that Mr Monroe had been desirous of the appointment of Major General, and that the Ladies of the family had told him they needed it to procure the common necessaries of life— This morning I walked round the Square alone— Governor Barbour brought me the draught of the Treaty prepared to be concluded with the Arkansas Cherokees now here. He said they were desirous of having an interview with me before they went home, and I agreed to receive them this day at one O’Clock. But Mr M’Kenney afterwards wrote me that two of them were unwell, and they wished the meeting with me to be postponed until to-morrow. Mr Breese the U.S. District Attorney in Illinois called and left with me a Memorial or Statement of Samuel Smith of that State; claiming certain Land-grants, to which the Commissioner of the General Land Office and the Secretary of the Treasury think him not entitled— There were two or three other papers relating to the case— Mr Breese said Mr Smiths wish was to appeal to my decision— Major Nourse called from the War Department to ask for a Certificate for 6747 dollars 50 Cents Six per Cent Stocks of 1813. issued to President Madison, for the benefit of the Seneca Indians; which being to be paid off next July, Mr Nourse desired me to transfer the Certificate to the Treasurer of the United States, which
I did— I had advised Mr Rush to have this stock re-invested in three per Cents— Major Hoops came and entertained me surely more than an hour upon the transcendant importance of an entire and radical reform in the system of military Store-keeping— I have not had time to peruse his little volume upon the subject, and he now read to me, and left with me an abstract or Summary of it, which he thought might serve to substitute for it— I listened to him with patience, and promised to hear him again before his return to Watervliet where he is stationed— We had company to dine— Dr. Aaron Bancroft, Ephraim Bateman, Sidney Breese, James Clarke, John Davis, William H. Harrison and Thomas Metcalfe— I had invited also C. Dorsey, Richard A. Buckner, Mr Jenifer, and Coll Taylor of Kentucky, and also Major Hoops, but they were engaged or made excuse— My Sons both dined with a large party at Mr Clay’s— Edward Wyer spent part of the Evening with me in my Chamber— I sent this day, Message N. 10. to Congress, concerning the African Negroes, landed last December at Key West from the stranded Spanish Slave trader— Gave also to my Son George Certificate N. 1720 of U.S. 6 per Cent Stock of 1813. for 1203. dollars to be paid off the first of July next.

Day. As the last Month— Excepting that after my Morning walk, still round the Capitol Square I now pass about an hour in the garden, visiting the plants and flowers— My Son George has been with us from the 12th his birth day—but is to leave us upon his return home to-morrow— He has sometimes cheered my early walk by bearing me company— My daily visitors increase in numbers; and I have not now regularly either morn or eve for writing— Yet these are yet Halcyon days.
